name: 3.1.3 - Import Time Lazy Error Fixes
body:
## Change Log

* Fix lazy error attrs as decorators (#64)
* Fix lazy error attrs as type hints (#65)
* Fix inheritance from lazy error attr (#63)

name: 3.1.2 - Lazy import error inheritance fix
body:
## Change Log

* Fix for bug with inheriting from a class that has been trapped by lazy imports (#63)

name: 3.1.1 - Lazy import errors meta path fixes
body:
## Change Log

* Fix bugs with how `lazy_import_errors` interacts with other libraries that also modify `sys.meta_path` (#62)

name: 3.1.0 - Show Optional
body:
## Change Log

* Add support for identifying optional dependencies (inside `try/except/finally`) (#61)
* Readme updates (#60)

name: 3.0.0 - Complete Overhaul
body:
## Description

This is a major change! It fundamentally rewrites the core logic for tracking imports and rearranges the arguments to the import tracking functionality. The high-level gist is:

* Rather than capturing imports during the processing of an `import_module`, the imports are computed after importing the target module by recursively inspecting the bytecode for all modules stemming from the target.
* The tracking no longer needs to launch `subprocesses` to perform recursion because it does not rely on the diff in `sys.modules`
* It's _way_ faster!

## But why?

Ok, the old way was working pretty well, so why refactor it all? The obvious answer is `speed`, but the less obvious answer is actually the correct one: the old implementation was not answering the right question. The old implementation answered the question

```
What modules are brought into sys.modules between starting the import of <target> and concluding the import of <target>?
```

Instead, what we _really_ want to know is:

```
If we stripped away all code not required for <target>, what modules would we need to have installed for the import of <target> to work?
```

The difference here comes down to whether you count siblings of nested dependencies. This is much easier to describe with an example:

```
deep_siblings/
├── __init__.py
├── blocks
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── bar_type
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   └── bar.py # imports alog
│   └── foo_type
│       ├── __init__.py
│       └── foo.py # imports yaml
└── workflows
    ├── __init__.py
    └── foo_type
        ├── __init__.py
        └── foo.py # imports ..blocks.foo_type.foo
```

In this example, under the old implementation, `workflows.foo_type.foo` would depend on both `alog` and `yaml` because the `..blocks` portion of the import requires that _all_ of the dependencies of `blocks` be brought into `sys.modules`. This, however, voids the value proposition of finding separable import sets. Under the new implementation, `workflows.foo_type.foo` only depends on `yaml` because it imports `blocks.foo_type.foo` from the deepest point where the only requirement is `yaml`.

## What breaks in the API?

* The `side_effects_modules` argument is gone. This was a hack to work around the fact that there were some modules that, when trapped by a `DeferredModule` would cause the overall import to fail. With the refactor, this is unnecessary as the import proceeds exactly as normal with no interferance.
* The output with `track_import_stacks` is different. It no longer attempts to look like stack traces, but it is actually more useful. Now, instead of a partially-useful stack trace, it's a list of lists where each entry is a stack of module imports that causes the given dependency allocation.
* By default, `import_module` stops looking for imports at the boundary of the target module's parent library. This means that if a third party module transitively imports another third party module, it won't be allocated to the target _unless_ `full_depth=True` is given.
* `LazyModule` is gone! This tool was a bit of a hack anyway and is no longer necessary.

name: 2.2.2 - Fix transitive detection for nested modules
body:
## Change Log

* 🐛  Fix how `direct` vs `transitive` is determined for attributes of modules that are defined in sub-modules (#53)

name: 2.2.1 - LazyModule trigger bug
body:
## Change Log

* Fix the bug where a `LazyModule` was triggered to import by the `import_tracker` main itself (#51)

name: 2.2.0 - Direct vs Transitive
body:
## Change Log

* Add support for `--detect_transitive` to label each dependency as either `direct` or `transitive` (#47)
* Use the `direct/transitive` information in `parse_requirements` to fix missing common dependencies for direct dependencies of parent modules that are shadowed by child extras (#49)

name: 2.1.1 - Fix release test
body:
## Change Log

* Fix the build process to retry when installing the newly released version (hopefully!) (#44)

name: 2.1.0 - Updated logic for extras_modules in parse_requirements
body:
## Change Log

* Update the logic when `extras_modules` are given to `parse_requirements` to include the dependencies of non-extra submodules in the common base dependency set (#41)

name: 2.03 - Fix PPA python support
body:
## Change Log

* Fix support for python builds from PPA (#40)
* Fix the unit tests to actually run against the target python versions

name: 2.0.2 - Single extras set
body:
## Change Log

* Add better support for a single `extras_modules` set in `parse_requirements` (#39)

name: 2.0.1 - Fast lazy import errors
body:
## Change Log

* Speed up lazy import errors (#37)

name: 2.0.0 - Allow iterables of strings in parse_requirements
body:
## Change Log

* 💥 Allow `parse_requirements` to take an iterable of strings in addition to a path to a file
    * This is an API breaking change due to the name change from `requirements_file` -> `requirements`

name: 1.4.0 - Extras-aware errors
body:
## Change Log

* Add support for augmenting `ModuleNotFoundError`s with information about which `extras` set to install (#29)
* Bug fix for parsing the name of the `import_tracker` module itself (#32)
* Readme updates

name: 1.3.0 - Import Stack Tracing
body:
## Change Log

* Add option to include stack trace information for imports (#27)

name: 1.2.0 - Limited recursion sub-modules
body:
## Change Log

* Add the ability to specify `--submodules` and limit which modules are traversed with `--recursive` (#28)
* Make `parse_requirements` more efficient by avoiding recursing on modules that are not being tracked as extras (#25)

name: 1.1.1 - Handle degenerate dynamic modules
body:
## Change Log

* Fix handling of modules created using `imp.new_module` (#26)

name: 1.1.0 - Side Effect Modules
body:
## Change Log

* Add support for specifying modules with side effects that should always be imported (#24)

name: 1.0.2 - Allow compiled third-party libs
body:
## Change Log

* Fix tracking for third-party libraries that are compiled as `.so` files (eg via `cython`) (#23)

name: 1.0.1 - Fix Lazy Import Error Tracking
body:
## Change Log

* Fix tracking for libraries that use `lazy_import_errors` (#22)

name: 1.0.0 - Initial Release
body:
## Change Log

This is the initial "official" release! It provides a set of stable uses:

* Run directly: `python3 -m import_tracker --name <my_module>`
* Enable lazy import errors: `with import_tracker.lazy_import_errors(): ...`
* Programmatically determine arguments to `setuptools.setup`: `import_tracker.setup_tools.parse_requirements(...)`

name: 0.0.8 - All requirements group
body:
## Change Log

* `setup_tools.parse_requirements` now adds a special `"all"` group to `extras_require` that will alias to the union of all optional dependency sets

name: 0.0.7 - Setup Tools and Lazier Errors
body:
## Change Log

* Add new `import_tracker.setup_tools.parse_requirements` that produces the `requirements` and `extras_require` arguments for `setuptools.setup`
* Defer import errors further so that most import-time attribute usage does not raise for missing optional dependencies
* For imports with no known package mapping, assume the import name is the package
* Expose `LazyModule` as part of the public API since its useful for consuming projects

name: 0.0.6 - Get tracked imports
body:
## Change Log

* Add `get_tracked_imports` to allow libraries to introspect all of their tracked imports

name: 0.0.5 - Tracking env passthrough
body:
## Change Log

* Pass through the full environment when running in TRACKING mode

name: 0.0.4 - Test coverage
body:
## Change Log

* 100% unit test coverage
* Raise `ValueError` instead of `ImportError` when querying `get_required_imports` for untracked module
* Pass all of `sys.path` to the subprocess in `TRACKING` mode

name: 0.0.3 - README cleanup
body:
## Change Log

* Clean up the `README` for a user-focused audience on PyPI

name: 0.0.2 - Initial automated release
body:
## Change Log

* First release cut via automation!
